message.content: {"steps":[{"output":"\\int_0^{\\frac{\\pi}{2}} 2\\sin x \\, dx","explanation":"Step 1 [Identify the integral to be solved]: We need to evaluate the definite integral \\( \\int_0^{\\frac{\\pi}{2}} 2\\sin x \\, dx \\)."},{"output":"2 \\int_0^{\\frac{\\pi}{2}} \\sin x \\, dx","explanation":"Step 2 [Factor out the constant]: The constant 2 can be factored out of the integral, giving us \\( 2 \\int_0^{\\frac{\\pi}{2}} \\sin x \\, dx \\)."},{"output":"-\\cos x","explanation":"Step 3 [Find the antiderivative]: The antiderivative of \\( \\sin x \\) is \\( -\\cos x \\)."},{"output":"2 \\left[-\\cos x \\right]_0^{\\frac{\\pi}{2}}","explanation":"Step 4 [Apply the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus]: Evaluate the antiderivative from 0 to \\( \\frac{\\pi}{2} \\). This gives us \\( 2 \\left[-\\cos x \\right]_0^{\\frac{\\pi}{2}} \\)."},{"output":"2 \\left[ -\\cos \\frac{\\pi}{2} + \\cos 0 \\right]","explanation":"Step 5 [Substitute the limits]: Substitute the limits into the antiderivative: \\( 2 \\left[ -\\cos \\frac{\\pi}{2} + \\cos 0 \\right] \\)."},{"output":"2 \\left[ 0 + 1 \\right] = 2","explanation":"Step 6 [Simplify the expression]: \\( \\cos \\frac{\\pi}{2} = 0 \\) and \\( \\cos 0 = 1 \\), so the expression simplifies to \\( 2 \\times 1 = 2 \\)."}],"final_answer":"\\MC: boxed{5}"}
